componenttext: Next question is from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Just with regard to the Texas freeze, it looks like the -- that lost revenue came at a high decremental margin, if my numbers are correct. Could you please elaborate on just how that impacted? And now that we're near the end of April, have you seen the fu
componenttext: Just with regard to the Texas freeze, it looks like the -- that lost revenue came at a high decremental margin, if my numbers are correct. Could you please elaborate on just how that impacted? And now that we're near the end of April, have you seen the full $0.15 impact? Or is this going to drag on through the fall on through the second quarter, possibly third? Just curious what type of lag there is occurring.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's good. So the Texas freeze, we expected this $0.15, which seems to be the right number as we speak. $0.10 have impacted Q1 as we communicated, and we expect the remaining $0.05 to impact Q2. We see things really so moving behind us. It's not a pe
componenttext: Yes, it's good. So the Texas freeze, we expected this $0.15, which seems to be the right number as we speak. $0.10 have impacted Q1 as we communicated, and we expect the remaining $0.05 to impact Q2. We see things really so moving behind us. It's not a perfect science. As you can imagine, what flows, what was closed, when it reopened, this is something that we can't control as such. But what I like is that things are really sort of back in operations. That's true for our customers. It's true for us and our suppliers as well. The only issue we had was impacting mostly March and April, which was obviously across 2 quarters, but 15 is the total number, 10 in Q1, 5 in Q2, and it's happening as expected.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: And it appears largely in the Industrial segment, where if I back that out, the weather impact, very elevated margins. Just curious what incremental upside do you see in the segment going forward? It looks very strong since the onset of the pandemic and s
componenttext: And it appears largely in the Industrial segment, where if I back that out, the weather impact, very elevated margins. Just curious what incremental upside do you see in the segment going forward? It looks very strong since the onset of the pandemic and strengthening.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: You're right that the margin work in Industrial has been remarkable. Over the past few years, it was over 300 basis points in 2020, while sales were slightly declining as you know. So in Q1, ex Texas, that was also a double-digit operating increase, which
componenttext: You're right that the margin work in Industrial has been remarkable. Over the past few years, it was over 300 basis points in 2020, while sales were slightly declining as you know. So in Q1, ex Texas, that was also a double-digit operating increase, which was good as well. And going forward, I believe that, that's a winning business. There will be times with raw materials and pricing, where quarter-over-quarter things might lag a little bit. But generally, margins will continue to improve in Industrial, especially because the value that we provide to our customers is unmatched. As mentioned before, most of the customers are coming to us, especially in our water business, is to help them reach the ESG commitments that they've made for 2030 or 2050, well, there's no one else that can truly help them as we can. This is something that is driving growth, and it's driving margins as well for us because they need better technology, which is where we invest most in research as well. That's where we have the highest margin. So it's good growth driven by good natural impact, which is driving as well our margin. So the short answer to your question, margins in Industrial are going to keep improving.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Next question is coming from the line of Laurence Alexander with Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question is coming from the line of Laurence Alexander with Jefferies.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the margin discussion and the price versus raws. As you look at 2022, 2023, should margins be for the entire firm be hitting a new high?
componenttext: Just following up on the margin discussion and the price versus raws. As you look at 2022, 2023, should margins be for the entire firm be hitting a new high?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. So it's hard for us to know exactly how it's going to be in '21. So knowing '22 and '23 will be even harder. The way we drive pricing is really sort of driven by the value that we create for our customers. In other words, how much s
componenttext: It's a great question. So it's hard for us to know exactly how it's going to be in '21. So knowing '22 and '23 will be even harder. The way we drive pricing is really sort of driven by the value that we create for our customers. In other words, how much savings we help them deliver in a year. They invest 10 in our services, and they get up 20% or plus back as a return. This is the way we price. It's basically so sharing how much value we create for our customers. Obviously, when there are raw material increases, like we are and will be experiencing in the next quarters and probably years to come. Well, we add that to the equation. We've been quite successful over the past few years in doing that. That's been one of the reasons why margins have improved so well over the past few years and especially as well last year. So I don't know how raws are going to be in '22 and '23. But I know that our pricing is going to keep being in the 1% to 2% plus range depending on how the raw materials market are, but it's never going to go down. So all all, it's going to be up in price, and it's going to be driving margins up as well over the long term.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: And then are there any end markets where you have been surprised at the elasticity of demand and where you're seeing a clear trade-off between pricing and organic growth?
componenttext: And then are there any end markets where you have been surprised at the elasticity of demand and where you're seeing a clear trade-off between pricing and organic growth?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: You mean in a negative manner?
componenttext: You mean in a negative manner?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Just -- I mean, has anything changed in your framework over the course of the COVID-related disruptions? Have you learned anything new about kind of the end market behavior, where you're like, look, that was not expected?
componenttext: Just -- I mean, has anything changed in your framework over the course of the COVID-related disruptions? Have you learned anything new about kind of the end market behavior, where you're like, look, that was not expected?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: No. If anything, it's more interest on one hand, so driven by this this increased trend of ESG of sustainability commitments. So what we do for customers becomes even more critical and customers are ready to invest in order to get more return from a finan
componenttext: No. If anything, it's more interest on one hand, so driven by this this increased trend of ESG of sustainability commitments. So what we do for customers becomes even more critical and customers are ready to invest in order to get more return from a financial perspective, but also from an image perspective because they make commitments as well out there. But on the other hand, it's also in times where performance -- cost performance becomes more important think about some of the end markets are economically challenged right now. Well, our solutions usually are very healthy for those customers because it helps them improve their cost competitiveness because you can do the same work the same outcome or better outcome with much less labor or creating less waste or using less natural resources as well. So it's a good financial deal. So on both sides for customers in most segments, well, they need more of what we do in order to reduce the impact on the environment. And while they do so, they reduce their cost as well, which is even more important in difficult economic times in some of the specific end markets. In both cases, this is a good story for us.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Andrew Wittmann with W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Andrew Wittmann with W. Baird.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: You had a couple of questions on margins. I wanted to do another one. You had the one on the industrial segment, you had a consolidated margin question. But I had a kind of a 2-part question here. On the health care segment, to start out with. Obviously,
componenttext: You had a couple of questions on margins. I wanted to do another one. You had the one on the industrial segment, you had a consolidated margin question. But I had a kind of a 2-part question here. On the health care segment, to start out with. Obviously, you talked about some of the large governmental orders and other things that probably helped your fixed cost leverage in that segment over the past 12 months. I was just wondering, as those comparisons are now stiffer and the business starts to normalize above historical levels, but starts to normalize from last year at least. If you think that some of the fixed cost leverage goes away, if that's the appropriate way of thinking about that segment's margins in the 12 months ahead? And then secondarily, just maybe a little bit more detail on the Institutional segment margins. Obviously, the volume declines were significant and it all makes sense, what happened to the margins so far. But on the way back up with the cost reductions and programs that you've put in place, do you think that when the revenue level gets back to 2019 levels, is there any reason to think that the margins would be any different in that business than they were pre-COVID just recognizing that the customer base is probably going to be somewhat changed, maybe not so much given national accounts, but there are a lot of changes to hospitality and foodservice. So I wanted to get your thoughts on that. Sorry for the long question.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: No, that's good. Thank you, Andy. Maybe starting with Healthcare, very different dynamic, obviously, than in Institutional. So in Healthcare, first of all, very pleased with the underlying growth performance or moving towards this 5%, which was an objecti
componenttext: No, that's good. Thank you, Andy. Maybe starting with Healthcare, very different dynamic, obviously, than in Institutional. So in Healthcare, first of all, very pleased with the underlying growth performance or moving towards this 5%, which was an objective for a long time. It's taken us so many years so to get there. And COVID has helped because the infection prevention, awareness of customers and patients, in that case, well, has gone up very clearly during COVID-19, so which is good. So underlying growth, solid in Healthcare, and that's here to stay. Second, on margins, very good improvement last year. In some cases, helped partly with the one-offs, those government deals that we talked about earlier. But I feel really good that margins is going to keep improving in '21 and in the future as well. So this is here to stay. So good story in Healthcare. And for me, that's not the end of the story. It's clearly so up to us to improve it further. That's on Healthcare. Institutional is a very different story, especially coming out of 2020, which is a business that's been impacted the most in our company. 90% plus of the COVID impact at Ecolab was on Institutional division, as we all know, which is 20% of our overall company as such. So when I think about the margins, I'd say 2 things, Andy. The first one is every quarter, it's going to improve, and we're going to get a lot back from what we lost in 2020, and we'll get close to where we were in 2019, pre-pandemic. So probably not at the end of this year, but early in 2022. And the second part of your question, so post-pandemic, if I can call it that way. Well, we've invested in our organizational development/restructure. We've invested as well in field technology that's going to help us well the performance. So if anything, the margins of institutional over the midterm should improve versus what we have seen pre-pandemic.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Shlomo Rosenbaum with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Shlomo Rosenbaum with Stifel.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Christophe, maybe you could talk a little bit about the discussion it used to be before the pandemic, a lot more about the investments that were being made in digital solutions. I know the company didn't want to pull back on investments through the pandem
componenttext: Christophe, maybe you could talk a little bit about the discussion it used to be before the pandemic, a lot more about the investments that were being made in digital solutions. I know the company didn't want to pull back on investments through the pandemic. Can you talk about what has happened over the last year, where there have been areas of adoption that have been accelerated because of the pandemic and where like the areas lag?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Great question. Thank you, Shlomo. Digital has been an important priority for us for many, many years. It started 30 years ago, actually, it was called differently obviously back then, that was true when we did remote monitoring of pools and spa in Instit
componenttext: Great question. Thank you, Shlomo. Digital has been an important priority for us for many, many years. It started 30 years ago, actually, it was called differently obviously back then, that was true when we did remote monitoring of pools and spa in Institutional and that was especially true, so we 3D TRASAR in industrial water business as well. And if I fast forward, ultimately, so for 2020 things have accelerated because in many instances, we could not go to customer locations for obvious reasons related to COVID. So customers and our teams have embraced digital solutions even more than before. Keep in mind as well that we've invested over the past 5 years, over $150 million a year in digital. So we were ready for that moment during the pandemic that was more luck than genius, obviously, as such, but it came very handy as well as such. So when I think about the 3 main drivers for us in digital at Ecolab, the first one is to drive customer value. So it's subscriptions, it's a Legionella prevention programs, for instance, as well. They're all driven by digital technology. We sell that technology. This is growing very nicely. The second one is our field solutions in order to improve the productivity and the value created by our 25,000 people around the world. Institutional has rolled out everywhere around the world, the new platform doing COVID, and that's going to help us as well. So for post-pandemic, that's what I just answered as well before, which is one of the reasons why our performance in institutional will improve. And the last pillar give the customer experience, e-commerce, for instance, that has gained traction in 2020 also because of the remote nature of the customer relationship that we had during the pandemic. So all 3 fronts, good progress in 2020. And when I look at the progress we're making in digital in 2021, our digital-enabled sales are roughly $1.5 billion and growing double-digit as we speak. So a very good story all in all.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. If I could follow-up, is there any progress to note in -- when the new verticals was going to be kind of the data center area. Is there anything to gain a report on that over the last year or quarters?
componenttext: Okay. Great. If I could follow-up, is there any progress to note in -- when the new verticals was going to be kind of the data center area. Is there anything to gain a report on that over the last year or quarters?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Well, it's been a great story because we've all ended up working remotely on whatever is your system of preference, Webex, Teams, Zoom and so on, remote monitoring of applications as well or plants. It's an industry that has been booming, as you can see a
componenttext: Well, it's been a great story because we've all ended up working remotely on whatever is your system of preference, Webex, Teams, Zoom and so on, remote monitoring of applications as well or plants. It's an industry that has been booming, as you can see as well from the numbers from the tech industry that we serve. Early last year, which was also pre-pandemic, we created our global data centers as a dedicated business, which game luckily enough, so very handy so for the pandemic. And since then, this business has been growing strong double-digit, operating income improvement very strong as well. And interestingly enough, so the customers that we serve, which are the tech companies, the ones are owning those data centers operations, at the same time, have made big commitments in terms of water and carbon savings. Well, this is the work we do for them because that's ultimately where they use the water or emit CO2 because of the energy that they need to use for the computers as such, which brought them back to us. You've heard from Microsoft as well. They've shared it openly publicly, so it's not a secret that they've committed for the net 0 water by 2030, and that's a plan that we've developed with them. That's all driving the growth in that new vertical, which is very promising.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: When you think about the restaurant and hotel business going forward, is the restaurant of the future going to be different than the restaurant of the past or the hotel of the future. That is there may be distancing rules, there may be other factors? Does
componenttext: When you think about the restaurant and hotel business going forward, is the restaurant of the future going to be different than the restaurant of the past or the hotel of the future. That is there may be distancing rules, there may be other factors? Does the Ecolab institutional business go back to where it was in 2019 in a normal environment? Or does it go to a different place? Is it better? Is it worse?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: This is a great question and a fundamental question, and it's not going to go back to where it was in 2019. I think it's going to be better. If I think about our end markets, it's not going to be true for everyone. For the independents, it's being difficu
componenttext: This is a great question and a fundamental question, and it's not going to go back to where it was in 2019. I think it's going to be better. If I think about our end markets, it's not going to be true for everyone. For the independents, it's being difficult, obviously, for individual restaurants during the endemic financially so to survive. Those ones have more hot ship than the chain customers, which is the vast majority of our business. So corporate account customers, as we call them, or the chains, are the ones who have well survived, the ones who have invested in the operations and the one who are expanding as well in terms of units. This is all we serve first and foremost. So that's a good situation to be in for us. Then to your question on the restaurant or the hotel of the future. To know exactly how it's going to be is hard to tell. But a few things we know. On one hand, so the hygiene standards are expected by the guests will be up versus 2019. It's going to be a little bit lower than during the pandemic, thank god, but it's going to be higher than 2019 and that's pretty sure. And we are asking guests or consumers all the time in order to understand. So what's happening in their mind, and they're clearly telling us that they're expecting higher hygiene standards, more clean, they want to see clean in action in order to feel safe, which is good. Second, the labor shortage is going to become a bigger issue. It was an issue pre-pandemic. It's going to be even more. So going forward, as we read in the newspaper. Well, our solutions are helping them deliver more with less labor. Which is good as well as search. And the last thing, which is harder to grasp completely is how much the takeout, the delivery is going to grow. It's going to keep growing for sure. And those are new opportunities for us because those are new businesses as well. We haven't figured it out completely, but I see that as upside. So net-net, for our customers, the chain customers, it's going to be different than '19, but it's going to be better for us as a company going forward.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021

componenttext: Okay. And what percentage of cost of goods sold or raw materials for you?

componenttext: It's roughly 45%, but obviously, it depends a lot by business. Pest elimination is much lower, as you can imagine. And in some industrial businesses, it might be higher, but average, it's 45% for the company.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021

componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Mike Harris with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up for Christophe. Earlier, you mentioned that the first quarter results gave you confidence that you could surpass the 2019 earnings level. I was just curious, I mean, what happened in the quarter that was, I guess, a positive surpris
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up for Christophe. Earlier, you mentioned that the first quarter results gave you confidence that you could surpass the 2019 earnings level. I was just curious, I mean, what happened in the quarter that was, I guess, a positive surprise to your internal expectations that kind of boosted your confidence?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Mike. The bigger question so for us for Q1 was to know, one, especially in the U.S. would reopen. And as you remember, in Q4, lockdown so went backwards in Q4 versus Q3. Well, that was not exactly a great news. And still, we improved our
componenttext: Well, thank you, Mike. The bigger question so for us for Q1 was to know, one, especially in the U.S. would reopen. And as you remember, in Q4, lockdown so went backwards in Q4 versus Q3. Well, that was not exactly a great news. And still, we improved our performance in Q4 versus Q3. So the question was, how is it going to continue in Q1. And that we didn't know, obviously as we started our year '21. So we were hoping that things would be improving. And ultimately, they did. But they did not in January or February, they did in March. So we were thinking, so Q1 would be a difficult quarter compared versus Q4, so modest improvement. Ultimately, ex Texas, it was better than what we felt in Q1. So if I look at that, the reopening in the U.S. states is a good news. Obviously, so for us going forward, China has been good since the beginning of the year. So those 2 markets are really on the positive side of the ledger. The other hand, so you have Europe and some emerging markets like Brazil or India that are in a more difficult situation. So net-net, it's basically as expected. And the last thing that I would say is that because of the timing of the reopenings in Europe, that's going to happen. So towards the end of Q2, some of the growth that we had expected in Q2 might shift in the but all in all, so I feel that net-net, the trends are as expected. Our cost structure is as expected. The timing might be a little bit different than what we had in mind initially, but at the end of the year, so it ends up to this full year delivery that's ahead of the EPS '19 excluding this Texas impact.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: Next question is from the line of Eric Petrie with Citi.
componenttext: Next question is from the line of Eric Petrie with Citi.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: I how much of your overall sales are to infection prevention? And if you could, to give a breakdown between Institutional and Healthcare?
componenttext: I how much of your overall sales are to infection prevention? And if you could, to give a breakdown between Institutional and Healthcare?

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021
componenttextpreview: So it's roughly 10% for the company, what we call sanitizing products. As such, it had very good growth. Last year that was especially true in Healthcare, which has a higher percentage, as you would expect, obviously, infection is a bigger part of what we
componenttext: So it's roughly 10% for the company, what we call sanitizing products. As such, it had very good growth. Last year that was especially true in Healthcare, which has a higher percentage, as you would expect, obviously, infection is a bigger part of what we do in hospitals than what we do in hotels or restaurants as you can imagine. But in both end segments, it grew double digit. And we expect the growth that we delivered in 2021 overall to maintain the overall number that we got in '21, which is a combination of more customers buying more of the sanitation products, but at the same time, with a little bit lower consumption. So much higher than what we had pre-pandemic, close to what we had in 2020 and close to the 10% for the overall sales.

headline: Ecolab Inc., Q1 2021 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2021

componenttext: Yes, it's one of the applications that we have. So we don't disclose too much, obviously, the formula that we are using as such. If you think about the 15 seconds of COVID kill that we launched on the market as well last year, this is an absolutely unique differentiated application. No one kills COVID-19 in 15 seconds or less than us. So that's been very unique and patented, obviously, on the market. But what you mentioned, so with the accelerated hydrogen peroxide, that's one of the solutions. We like it as well. We use it as well. But for us, we're going beyond that as well.
